B.VIII."But the Laced monians and confederates, so soon*' as the king's fleet shall be come up, shall have it in*' their own option to maintain, if they please, their"own fleet; or, in case they choose to take subsist-*f ence from Tissaphernes, he is bound to supply them.*' Yet the Laced monians and confederates, at the ex-"piration of the war, shall repay to Tissaphernes"whatever sums they may thus receive from him.*' When the king's fleet cometh up, let the ships"of the Laced monians, and those of the confede-"rates, and those of the king, carry on the war in con-"cert, by the joint counsels of Tissaphernes and of the** Laced monians and confederates."And, whenever a peace with the Athenians be"thought adviseable, it shall be concluded hy the joint"consent of both parties." The treaty was made and ratified in these terms. And, after this, Tissaphernes employed himself with diligence to bring up the Ph nician fleet, as hath been mentioned, and duly to perform all the branches what- ever of his engagements. At least he was willing to convince the Peloponnesians, by the measures he took, that he was heartily in earnest. In the close of this winter the B otians got possession of Oropus by treachery, though an Athenian garrison was in it. The business was effectuated by the ma- nagement of a party of Eretrians, and those Oropians who were plotting the revolt of Eub a. For, as this town was situated over-against Eretria, it was impossible but, whilst in Athenian hands, it must terribly annoy both Eretria and the rest of Eub a. Having therefore thus gained Oropus, the Eretrians repair to Rhodes, inviting the Peloponnesians to come over to Eub a; but their inclinations were rather to relieve Chios, how sadly distressed.
